children: Ensuring upper airway patency is the priority.
Patients with a visibly damaged airway or stridor require immediate intubation.
Cyanide exposure is common in house fires where cyanide is produced and aerosolized when vinyl burns. Cyanide is a common coexposure with carbon monoxide. A normal
level excludes cyanide poisoning. Treat cyanide poisoning with hydroxocobalamin.
Patients with inhalational injury involving the lower airways typically present with a clear chest x-ray; wheezing, cough, and dyspnea manifest 12 to 36 hours after exposure.
Normal oxygen saturation does not exclude either carbon monoxide or cyanide poisoning.
